title: Got a summons today from Capital One; they are suing me for $2,000, I am totally broke, and have no idea of how to answer
question: I have been researching on the internet on how to answer a summons, Im confused. I want to deny all allegations and give them the burden of proving that I owe what they say I owe. I have already sent a validation letter, which they nevered validated, HELP
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt settlement,Debt negotiation,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Discovery,Summons and complaint,Sued for debt,Default judgment,State court
answers:
A Summons is the real deal, you must deal with it by either settling immediately or answering the lawsuit and defending. If you do nothing a default judgment will be entered against you and they can use that to garnish wages, record liens and go after bank accounts. The filing fee for an limited civil case is $370.00; and that is just to get your answer filed.
If bankruptcy is an option, the bankruptcy will stop the State court lawsuit. Your cheapest option is to settle. Settlement gets more expensive the farther into this you go. There is a lot of bad advice about how to stall a lawsuit by making a bad faith answer and asking for discovery. Capital One files hundreds of lawsuits every week in every county of California. If you answer the lawsuit you may buy yourself some time; but will probably lose the lawsuit and the cost of filing and prosecuting the lawsuit may be added to what you owe.

The first thing is to read my blog posting, see link below, about your next steps when sued on a debt collection lawsuit. Also, please watch the short first video on the home page of my web site, which explains your six options, so you can determine which may suit your situation.

Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com
Twitter: @RStempler

No later than 30 days after someone handed the summons and complaint to you, you should file and serve an Answer http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/pldc010.pdf. Check box 3.a. ("Defendant generally denies each statement ...") and assert any and all appropriate affirmative defenses in section 4. Ideally, you should consult with a debt collections defense attorney. If you can't, then you should visit your local public law library and research affirmative defenses.
You need to respond to all allegations and you need to heed Mr. Stempler's advice.
